title: Treasury Eases Minimum-Tax Burdens on U.S. Multinationals
summary: Treasury Department issues rules implementing 2017 tax law. WASHINGTON-U.S.-based multinationals will be less exposed to certain U.S. taxes after the Treasury Department issued new rules implementing two major pieces of the 2017 tax law.

title: Trump Campaign Won't Approve Bloomberg Reporters' Credentials
summary: Campaign cites decision by outlet owned by candidate Mike Bloomberg to investigate Trump but not Democratic contenders. WASHINGTON-President Trump's re-election campaign said it no longer would approve credentials for Bloomberg News reporters after the company said it wouldn't investigate Democratic presidential candidates while its owner, Mike Bloomberg, sought the party's nomination.

title: Bloomberg in 2020: The Buyout, Not the Candidate
summary: Were the financial-data company Michael Bloomberg founded ever to do a deal, it would be a momentous event for fintech investors. When most people think about a race for Bloomberg, they probably have in mind Michael Bloomberg joining the Democratic primary. But investors might imagine something else entirely: the race for his eponymous financial data giant, Bloomberg LP.

title: J.Crew Gets Lender Approval for Madewell IPO
summary: Private-equity owners agree to invest up to $150 million as part of deal. J.Crew Group Inc. clinched a deal with creditors that paves the way for the struggling retailer to take its fast-growing denim-focused Madewell subsidiary public.

title: Trump Wins the Populist Patriots
summary: They see him defending their cultural beliefs from the left and their economic interests from the right.. Populist patriots reject the elites of both parties. They believe President Trump defends their cultural beliefs from the left and their economic interests from the right. They see open borders, illegal immigration and multiculturalism threatening to redefine what it means to be an American, while unfair trade and a rigged tax code endanger their jobs.

title: Will Bloomberg Buy the Election?
summary: No, but by losing he can put the lie to Democrats' claims about Citizens United.. If Joe Biden falters, the received wisdom runs, nominating Michael Bloomberg to head the Democratic ticket would boost the party's chances next November by pitting a strong, credible moderate against Donald Trump. It's possible. But the former mayor of New York could do his party an even bigger favor just by losing.

title: Don't Let Russia Dominate Libya
summary: A Kremlin-backed strongman in Tripoli would be a disaster for U.S. interests.. American interests are under attack in Libya, whether we realize it or not. Adversaries and allies alike are attempting to install a dictator. In doing so, they're undermining U.S. credibility and challenging American leadership of the international order.

title: Iran Takes Hard Line to Keep Protests Down
summary: People describe authorities demanding money to return bodies of their children killed by security forces. Days after 32-year-old Hamid Rasouli joined demonstrations over Iran's troubled economy, he was killed by security forces, according to a friend. They handed over his body to his family with two demands: Pay nearly $8,000 and say your son was a member of a state militia who died at the hands of protesters.

title: A Republican Proposal to Feed the Country to the Swamp
summary: Moving federal agencies to the heartland would get struggling states hooked on big government.. Progressives dream of making the District of Columbia into a state, but now a pair of Republican senators have the same vision reflected through a funhouse mirror. The Helping Infrastructure Restore the Economy Act would effectively transform 10 states into D.C. by moving at least 90% of jobs from 10 executive departments out of Washington and into "economically distressed regions" across the country.

title: 'Wind Chill' Is Hot Air
summary: What it 'feels like' is subjective. You can't reduce it to a number.. As winter blows in, meteorologists and apps alike are reporting lower and lower temperatures, but one figure they give you is pure nonsense: the wind chill.

title: Is There Real Virtue Behind the Business Roundtable's Signaling?
summary: When you break out the data, 'stakeholder capitalism' appears to fail on its own terms.. The Business Roundtable made a big splash in August by "modernizing its principles on the role of a corporation." No longer stressing the unique importance of maximizing shareholder value, the organization got 181 CEOs to sign a statement outlining a corporate commitment to various "stakeholders," of which shareholders are only one, listed alongside customers, employees, suppliers and communities.

title: 'Hop, Skip, Go' Review: Going Mobile
summary: A "mobility revolution" may well affect where we go and how fast we get there. Will it happen suddenly or unfold slowly, in incremental stages?. My condo building has an underground garage with some 250 parking spaces, each attached to a particular unit. Our board would like unit owners, should they wish, to have the option of installing chargers for electric cars; each owner would pay individually for the power consumed. But after many visits from engineers and electrical contractors, we've come up empty. It seems that a system of separately owned charging stations in a single building is more than current technology can deliver.

summary: 'The tribute was especially unusual, since Trump, who has never owned a pet, is clearly no fan of man's best friend.'. Judith Millerwriting for City Journal, Dec. 2:

title: U.S. Lifts Hold on Military Aid to Lebanon
summary: Administration hasn't said why more than $100 million in aid to Lebanese Armed Forces was suspended; concern about Hezbollah cited. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration has released more than $100 million in aid for Lebanon's military after suspending the assistance without explanation earlier in the fall, officials said Monday.

title: Leader's Resignation in Iraq Gives U.S. a Narrow Opening
summary: Complex political selection process, challenges from Iran complicate U.S. prospects for improvement with a necessary partner. The resignation of Iraq's prime minister presents the U.S. with an opportunity for a fresh start with an essential-if often frustrating-partner, but the Trump administration faces Baghdad's unpredictable succession process, entrenched political interests and competition from Iran, U.S. officials and independent experts said.

title: Political Uncertainty Pressures Emerging-Market Currencies
summary: Latin America has been among the worst hit; protests in Chile, other countries across region rattle investors. President Trump's announcement Monday that he would restore steel and aluminum tariffs on Argentina and Brazil marks the latest threat to economic activity in emerging markets, underscoring geopolitical fears that have hurt currencies world-wide.

title: Cloud Companies Can't Afford to Come Up Short
summary: Short interest has jumped among companies reporting this week. It is a big week for cloud companies-and potentially for a growing number of investors betting against them.

title: New York City Braces for Up to 6 Inches of Snow
summary: Storm complicates evening commute, but morning rush should be clear; upstate gets 'walloped'. New York City was expected to get 3 to 6 inches of snow on Monday, with the storm disrupting some evening commutes but ending hours before Tuesday's morning rush hour.

title: The President Was Right to Pardon the Seal CPO
summary: I feel that the Navy felt it needed "its piece" of Chief Gallagher. Unable to get a conviction for serious offenses, he was found guilty of a much lesser offense, which the president overturned.. Regarding your editorial "Trump and the SEALs" (Nov. 26): I'm a former Navy officer. I don't know Chief Petty Officer Edward Gallagher's character nor if he's a good CPO or a bad one. What I do know is that he was put on trial and prosecutorial ineptness tainted the process. I also know that the jury of officers would have felt compelled to convict him if the evidence was there, which it obviously wasn't.

title: Praise for Mr. Rogers's World, and a Dissent
summary: Many times Fred Rogers served as the father I never had. Heaven knows we all adored him.. Regarding Erica Komisar's "The Child-Rearing Wisdom of 'Mister Rogers' Neighborhood'" (op-ed, Nov. 23): It was heartening to read Dr. Komisar on the wisdom of Mr. Rogers regarding child rearing. As a psychiatrist who has practiced for more than 40 years and still does psychodynamic-psychoanalytic psychotherapy, I completely agree with her on the importance of empathetic parenting in raising decent human beings.

title: Nobody Thinks the 'Milk of Human Kindness' Is Dairy
summary: Anyone who eats buffalo wings, ladyfingers and monkey bread knows exactly what they're getting.. While associations with the words for familiar animal-based meats and milks certainly help create gustatory expectations (milk will be white and creamy; burgers will be round; and nuggets will be breaded, etc.), the bottom line is meanings evolve, context matters, and consumers aren't stupid ("The Modern Meaning of Meat," Review, Nov. 23). Anyone who eats buffalo wings, ladyfingers and monkey bread knows exactly what they're getting, and no one who orders a veggie burger, drinks almond milk or eats cashew cheese feels they're being duped.

title: There Can Be Community in Senior Life-Care Living
summary: Making new friends as one ages is an empowering and enriching experience. Aging in a life-care community will offer opportunities that technology cannot match.. Three years ago my husband and I moved to a nonprofit life-care community in Southern California, on the recommendation of my husband's physician. My husband died five months ago. I am in my late 70s and enjoy living in a community with a pool, gym, a walkable neighborhood, numerous intellectually stimulating activities and a supportive group of friends. I have dinner almost nightly with a fun and entertaining group of people.

title: The Earnings Data Should Include Non-College Careers
summary: Let's see the average earnings of a first-year licensed electrician, welder, plumber, etc. and the payback for the cost of those educations.. Regarding your editorial "What's Your Degree Worth?" (Nov. 21) The Education Department offers some valuable college data. Kudos to Secretary Betsy DeVos for shedding light on the true value of a college degree by breaking the subject down to which college and what degree one is talking about. She could complete her project by including various trade schools. Let's see the average earnings of a first-year licensed electrician, welder, plumber, etc. and the payback for the cost of those educations. She could include the money students earn while working toward their license.

title: Smaller Loaves of Bread Are on the Rise
summary: Bakers cook up new options to suit small households and millennials who don't want to waste food. Ms. Grady buys half loaves so her family can finish them before they go stale. The smaller loaves usually cost slightly more per slice but "I don't like throwing away food," says Ms. Grady, an analytics manager in Austin, Texas.
